awd_titl_txt: ABR: Field, Laboratory, and Numerical Studies of Geyser Eruptions
awd_abstract_narration:
Geysers are springs that intermittently erupt mixtures of steam and liquid water. They are popular tourist attractions, with a few million people watching geysers erupt in Yellowstone National Park each year. Geysers are the surface expression of geothermal systems and provide insight into heat and fluid flow in volcanically active areas. Geysers also provide a natural laboratory to study eruption processes and the geophysical and hydrological signals that can be measured before, during, and after an eruption. Because they are smaller than volcanic eruptions, and erupt more frequently, they provide an opportunity to collect abundant data and develop approaches for integrating and interpreting measurements. Geysers and their deposits have been studied to understand life in extreme environments. Geyser-like behavior of water and hydrocarbons has also been observed on the ocean floor and at mud volcanoes.  Thus improved understanding of geyser behavior may yield understanding into other self-organized, intermittent processes in nature that result from localized input of energy and mass. 

Despite two centuries of scientific study, explanations for geysering phenomena are limited or lacking. This project will integrate field measurements, laboratory studies, and numerical simulations of multiphase flow in geyser systems to address the following basic questions about the geysering process:  Why are geysers so rare? How does conduit plumbing affect eruption initiation and the interval between eruptions? Why and how do geysers interact with each other? Which external processes (e.g., tides, variations in barometric pressure, temperature variations, wind speed, earthquakes) and internal dynamics (e.g., duration of preceding eruption, plumbing geometry) influence the interval between and duration of eruptions? Answers to these questions may offer new insight into triggered seismicity, hydrothermal explosions, and volcanic eruptions.

por.por_cntn:
Geysers are springs that intermittently erupt mixtures of steam and liquid water. They provide a window into the transport of mass and energy in hydrothermal systems. To understand how and why geysers exist and erupt we used a multidisciplinary approach to study the iconic geysers of Yellowstone National Park, USA, and in Chile.

 

In Yellowstone National Park, we studied some of the largest geysers, including Steamboat, Old Faithful, Castle and Giant, to answer several fundamental questions about geysers: What structures are required to create geysers? Why do some geysers erupt regularly, and others do not? What controls eruption characteristics such as the volume erupted, the interval between eruptions, and the height to which geysers erupt? Using radiocarbon ages of trees that grew on the mound of silica precipitated from Old Faithful geyser, we showed that Old Faithful stopped erupting for more than about a century in the 13th century during an extended drought. Using radiocarbon ages at Giant and Castle geysers we showed that they probably formed following the retreat of glaciers. Geochemical measurements of the silica sinter precipitated by these geysers was used to determine how trace element concentration and mineral structure of the silica change over time. We found that sinters are enriched in Rare Earth Elements. The reactivation of Steamboat Geyser in 2018, the world's tallest geyser, provided an opportunity to answer several basic questions. We showed that reactivation was probably the result of dynamics within the subsurface hydrothermal system rather than from tectonic or seismic events. Variations in the interval between eruptions are influenced primarily by groundwater levels. We found that the great height of Steamboat is caused by its erupted water coming from a reservoir at greater depth than at other geysers.

 

In Chile we identified and characterized a new geyser field called Alpehue. Using drone-based mapping and geochemical measurements of water erupted by the geysers, we showed how glacial deposits and regional faults control the location of geysers and hot springs (see attached figure). At the El Tatio geyser field, the second largest on Earth, we used geochemical, temperature, and discharge measurements to determine the energy budget for the entire geothermal system. We also identified the source of water. From the silica sinter deposited by the El Tatio geysers, we showed that the sinter deposited on distal aprons of geysers where the water has cooled can preserve organic material that faithfully records a radiocarbon age of the deposit. With a large suite of radiocarbon measurements, we were then able to determine the age of the geothermal field and how the location of discharge migrated over time. Using data from broadband seismometers, we imaged the plumbing system beneath a geyser and found that the reservoir that hold fluids prior to eruption is offset from the conduit --  a feature that appears to be common at geysers. Offset reservoirs can accumulate fluids prior to eruption and then empty during eruption, enabling episodic eruption (a geyser) rather than continuous discharge (a hot spring).

 

This project provided multidisciplinary training (field work, laboratory experiments, synchrotron science, numerical simulation) for one undergraduate student, one graduate student, and one postdoc. The research team engaged with indigenous communities in Chile. Research was done in collaboration with researchers from the National Park Service and the US Geological Survey.
